factors.optimal: What do you want this factor to be? For instance, if taste is on a scale of 0-10, then we probably want it to taste good (10), but if it"s cost, we probably don"t want it to be expensive (0).
factors.weight: How much do you care about this factor? For instance, we probably don"t care much about how many leftovers it has, but we probably care a more about what it tastes like. If you"re unsure, we can tweak this later as well.
factors.scale: What are the bounds of this factor? For instance, if it"s on a scale of 0-10, then we probably want it to be between 0 and 10. If it"s not clear, however, you can select "Unbounded" to automatically calculate it from the answers you give. There may also be one but not the other, for example, for the "cost" factor, we know it"s not negative (no one is going to pay a *us* for a meal), but it could cost as much as we want. However, if you know you"re not going to spend more than $100, you can set the max to 100. Adding a scale explicitly is going to be more accurate than not.
factors.unit: This is to help you keep track of what the scale is. You can have the scale be anything you want, 0-10, dollars, miles, etc. For vauge factors, for example Taste, it"s probably easiest to use a 0-10 scale.
factors.factor: The name of the factor. You can put anything here: from "taste", to "happiness" to "how much I want to". Literally anything you can think of that relates to the decision you"re making. The more the better! Even things that are only slightly relevant will make the final answer more accurate.
factors.quick_add: If you just want to brain dump anything you can think of real quick, just select this and fill out the details later.
factors.explanation:
This page allows you to add, edit, and remove factors to your decision. Factors are anything that relates to the decision. Anything that would go on a pro-con list would be a factor. You can add as many as you want, and you can edit them later.
The more factors, the better. Feel free to be as specific as you want. If you're
just brainstorming, and want to add a bunch at once, you can use the `Quick Add`
option, then go back through afterwards to add the details.

Hover over the ? for more information on each field.

Note that after adding a factor, all the inputted answers *should* be reset. Unfortunately, that's not realistic in this prototype, but that is a feature I plan on adding in the app itself, so just ignore that.

After you've added some factors, head over to the `Fine Tune Weights` page
to adjust the weights of each factor.

dashboard.explanation:
This is (or will be) an app to help you make decisions!

Explanations for each page will be here.

Start by going to the `Decisions` page and add a new decision.
Then, if you have multiple decisions, you can come back here and switch between them. You can also click the `only for testing` box to add some pre-made decisions for testing (though I encourage you to make your own to test it first).

weights.explanation:
This is where you can fine tune how much each factor matters. Because getting
the weights right can have a large impact on the final answer, I've created a
seperate way to break it down as well. Remember, this is targeted towards making
big decisions that might have lots of factors.

If you think the weights you added when adding factors are already pretty accurate,
you can skip this step.

There's steps to fine tuning the factors. You can do either one, both, or neither
of them as you'd like. First, you can go through the section that helps you sort
the factors in order of importance. It breaks it down into pairs of factors
and asks which is more important. It uses a custom algorithm to make the sorting
as efficient as possible. It won't change any of the weights until you're done
sorting them, and then it will ask you if you want to set them as the new weights.

From there, you can go to the slider, which shows the weights next to each other.
You can adjust the weights by dragging the sliders, so they're not simply evenly
spaced. I've also included several graphs to help you visualize the weights.

Once you're done here, head over to the `Answers` page to start making the
decision.

decisions.explanation:
This page allows you to add, edit, and remove decisions to your dashboard. Decisions are
pretty self explanatory.

Once you're done here, go to the `Options` page to add options to your decision.

options.explanation:
This page allows you to add and remove options to your decision. Pretty self explanatory.

Once you're done here, go to the `Factors` page to add factors to your decision.

quiz.explanation:
Now that you've specified what the decision you're trying to make actually is, you can start inputting what you know. This page breaks down the decision into parts so you can evaluate each part of the decision induvidually. This part usually takes the longest. If you're not sure about an answer, you can skip it and come back to it later, or you can select "I'm not sure" and provide a range of values that you think is appropriate. The behind the scenes algorithm will take your uncertainty into account.

There are 2 options for inputting answers: 

1.A quiz, which will ask you each answer one at a time, and you can input it interactively. 

2. A manual input table, in which you can put the answers in directly, if that makes more sense to you. 

Once you're finished filling in all the answers, you can move on to the `View Results` page to finally see the results of your decision!

view_results.explanation:
This page shows the results of your decision. It shows the best option, the worst option, and graphs of the results to help you understand why they're the best and worst.

When providing feedback, you can use the letters on the right side to reference specific graphs.
view_results.line1d: This shows the results in terms of how "bad" each option is, or in other words, how far way each option is from the optimal
view_results.PCA: This shows each option as a point in 2D space. Each point is actually in a much higher dimension, but this is projected down to 2D to make it easier to visualize. (For those who are interested, it uses the PCA algorithm to do this.)
view_results.radar: Here you can see each option compared to each other, or the optimal. The more area that overlaps with the optimal, the better. Same with the worst.
view_results.heatmap1d: This shows your options in order of how good they are. The greener, the better. If all of the options are green, that means all of them are generally good options. If they're all red, that means you don't have many good options. The percentage is on a scale of worst possible to best possible.
view_results.entropy: This shows how much each factor contributed to the decision. Say you have a factor that we care a lot about, but all of the options are close each other. That factor didn't really contribute much to the decision, because they're all the same. But if all of the options are different for a given factor, then that's going to be a more useful factor. However, if we don't care about that factor, it still won't matter much. This is a measure of the "variability" of each factor, according to each factor's weight.
view_results.goodness_bar: This shows how good each option is on a scale of worst possible to best possible. The bar at the top shows the likely ranges of each option, if there are unknown values (ranges) in any of your answers.
view_results.contributions_var_size: This shows how much each answer contributed to each option. The green squares are good, while the red squares are bad. The size of the square is proportional to the weight of the factor. The percentages are essientially how "good" of an answer it is (compared to what we want it to be), and the numbers in the parenthesis are the given value/maximum value

save.explanation: This page allows you to export and import decisions. You can export a decision as a .dec file, and import a .dec file.

explanation.explanation: This page explains the details of how the algorithm works. Let me know if I've explained it clearly enough, and if the graphs are helpful.

factor_packs.explanation: This page allows you to add and remove factor packs to your decisions. These will be in-app purchases, but for now, just click 'buy' to mess with them. They're currently full of placeholder factors, and there's only 2. In the future, there will be more of them, they'll scroll to the side, and they'll have better pictures (probably).
factor_packs.page_explanation: Factor packs are pre-made groups of factors that apply to certain decisions.
